title: Bob Cooper (rugby league)
text:
Bob Cooper is an Australian former professional footballer. He played <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League">New South Wales Rugby League</a>. In 1982, Cooper was suspended for the equal-longest period in rugby league history.
Cooper played rugby league for <a href="Western%20Suburbs%20Magpies">Western Suburbs Magpies</a> and <a href="North%20Sydney%20Bears">North Sydney Bears</a> and, in 1980, was selected in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20state%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales team</a> for the <a href="1980%20Rugby%20League%20State%20of%20Origin%20game">inaugural game</a> in the <a href="Rugby%20League%20State%20of%20Origin">State of Origin</a>. He played primarily in the <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Back%20row">back row</a>. Cooper was named in the Western Suburbs Magpies Team of the Eighties, in the second-row.
In 1982, Cooper was suspended for the equal-longest period in rugby league history, of fifteen months, after he ran in to join a brawl and left three <a href="Illawarra%20Steelers">Illawarra Steelers</a> players flattened during a match at <a href="Wollongong%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Wollongong</a> showground. When imposing the suspension, the <a href="NSWRFL">NSW Rugby League</a> judiciary chairman, Jim Comans said, "Acts such as these must be obliterated from the game, and I'll begin by obliterating you." 
In 1983, Cooper played <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a> with <a href="St%20George%20AFC">St George</a> in the <a href="Sydney%20AFL">Sydney Football League</a> and won the reserve competition's <a href="best%20and%20fairest">best and fairest</a> award.
In 1984, Cooper returned to the NSW Rugby League with <a href="North%20Sydney%20Bears">North Sydney</a> but, after only four games, he dislocated his shoulder and retired from football.
